Subject files: Dionne quintuplets
Caption: Emilie, Cecile, Yvonne, Marie, Annette

Note: THE QUINTUPLETS GET A NEW NURSE: the Dionne Quintuplets were eager to show off their ability with camera, drawing pencil, musical instruments, etc., for their new nurse, Mlle. Gertrude Provencher, of the city of Quebec. L. to r.: Emilie, Yvonne (on floor, drawing), Cecile, Nurse Gertrude Provencher, Marie (with finger in mouth, tsk! tsk!), and Annette
Caption: Annette, Emilie, Yvonne, Marie, Cecile

Note: CECILE INCHING AHEAD IN QUINTUPLET GROWTH RACE: The Dionne Quints line up to be weighed, always a thrilling moment, for each is eager to grow faster than her sisters. Left to right: Annette, Emilie, Yvonne, Marie and Cecile, with Nurse Doreen Chaput

Subject files: The Explorers Club (Ford Exposition banquet for Admiral Richard E. Byrd)

FORD EXPOSITION BIDS GOODBYE TO ADMIRAL BYRD The Ford Exposition was host at New York's principal farewell banquet to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, about to leave on his third Antarctic Expedition, at the New York World's Fair. The banquet was organized by the Order of Adventures, and more than 200 national and international figures were guests. Left to right at the speakers' table are Phillips Carlin of the National Broadcasting Company; Captain Felix Riesenberg, retired naval officer, author and explorer; Senator Frederic C. Walcott of Connecticut; Frank E. Mason, vice president of the National Broadcasting Company; Mrs. Lenox Lohr; F.L. Black, in charge of the Ford Exposition; Mrs. Roy Chapman Andrews; Admiral Byrd; Lowell Thomas, famed radio commentator; Alice Roosevelt Longworth; Dr. Roy Chapman Andrews, director of the American Museum of Natural History; Mrs. Lowell Thomas; Major Lenox Lohr, president of the National Broadcasting Company; Mrs. Frank Mason; Col. Theodore Roosevelt; Leslie Bain, director of the Order of Adventures.

Subject files: The Explorers Club (Ford Exposition banquet for Vilhjalmur Stefansson)

Note: FORD HONORS STEFANSSON The Ford Motor Company gave a formal dinner in the Executive Suite of the Ford pavilion on August 23 in honor of the great Arctic explorer, scientist and author - Vilhjalmur Stefansson. Fred L. Black, Ford Exposition director, presided, and among the speakers were Sir Hubert Wilkins, Joseph Robinson and Reginald Orcutt. Scores of notables in the field of exploration and science attended. As guests entered the dining room Ford Information girls in fur parkas gave them flowers. Small polar bears were the table favors. In honor of Mr. Stefansson the Ford terrace, visible to the diners through the wall of clear glass, was decorated to represent an Arctic scene. A backdrop, illuminated by blue lights, showed an Eskimo family cooking dinner near an igloo, with open water, a floating iceberg and the aurora borealis in the distance. In the foreground was a set representing the interior of an igloo, containing a polar bear skin, a rifle and other trappings. Adjoining was a loaded dog sled, with a team of live huskies tethered nearby, squatting in artificial snow. In the foreground a man in parka and mukluks cooked his dinner on a primus stove. This photo shows Joseph Robinson, Vilhjalmur Stefansson, Sir Hubert Wilkins and Reginald Orcutt.

Subject files: The Explorers Club (Ford Exposition banquet for Sir Hubert Wilkins)

Note: FORD EXPOSITION HONORS SIR HUBERT WILKINS Fifty friends of Sir Hubert Wilkins, famous polar explorer, gathered in the Executive Suite of the Ford Exposition, New York World's Fair, on July 29. The occasion was a formal dinner given for Sir Hubert and Lady Wilkins by the Ford Motor Company. Sir Hubert had just returned from France (he was in Paris the day before it fell) and Britain. Fred L. Black, director of the Ford Exposition, welcomed the guests in behalf of the Ford Motor Company. Besides Sir Hubert speakers were Lowell Thomas and Joseph Robinson. Guests included distinguished members of the Explorers Club and others. In this photo: Sir Hubert Wilkins, Mr. Lowell Thomas

Hitchcock, President of the club. Among the explorations carried out by Mr. Hoover were those he made in his younger days as a mining and petroleum engineer

Note: LT with a 95 year old explorer who was with Theo. [Theodore] Roosevelt on his River of Doubt expedition - up the Amazon. His name Carl von Hoffman: phone Explorers Club and asked the secy. for his name. Also a young potential explorer. 46 E 70th Explorers Bldg. Note: Anderson, IN., Nov. 8, 1977, Dear Lowell: Here is a print of the Lowell Thomas Building dedication. Ernie Schmidt took the picture and sent me the slide. If by chance you would like a larger print I could send you one. I trust that your Tibetan trip was all that you had hoped for. I would love to hear a report of it soon. Unfortunately, I will miss our Annual Dinner next spring due to the fact that I will be on expedition in the Sahara again. I send my regards to Marianna. Sincerely, your friend, Howell. Howell L. Joiner

Subject files: First World Flight

Note: In 1924 eight U. S. Army airmen, years before there was a "U. S. Air Corps and then a U. S. Air Force" , in four bi-planes (Douglas World Cruisers), started out to circumnavigate the globe by air. It was the greatest international air race of all time. None of the planes from the six European countries that already had entered the race, succeeded in getting more than half-way around. One American plane, The Flagship, flown by Major Frederick Martin and Sgt. Al Harvey crashed in Alaska. ; These are the six flyers who made it all the way around, with L. T., historian of the flight, and Vi Moseley, for a time L. T.'s secretary. She had been secretary to Gen. Billy Mitchell, who had been rejected from the Army because his ideas were too far advanced. He knew air power would soon be predominant but his superiors, all Army Generals, were not sufficiently far-sighted enough to agree. This flight was one of the major mile-stones in the history of man, and actually launched the travel-by-air-era. World War II airmen with surplus World War II planes, launched the first aerial passenger service a year after the conclusion of this flight. America following their example in 1926. ; The names of the First World Flyers were: reading from left to right: - Lt. Leslie Arnold, who later helped Eddie Rickenbacker launch Eastern Airlines; Lt. John Harding; Lt. Erik Nelson, later a Vice President of Boeing and one of the men who launched SAS; Lt. Leigh Wade, who became a World War II Air Force General; Lt. Lowell Smith, who became the Second Commander of the First World Flight and several years later was killed in Arizona; and Lt. Henry H. Ogden, who became a civilian aviation expert [Lowell Thomas, second from right]
Verso: (for Pherbie) left to right

S. round the world flight planes at Dutch Harbor, Unalaska, shows one of the planes after being placed on the wharf to be overhauled. The fourth, Major F. L. Martin's plane, the Seattle, was then reported missing for the first time

LIEUT. WADE'S DISABLED PLANE BROUGHT ALONGSIDE CRUISER RICHMOND IN NORTH ATLANTIC; This EXCLUSIVE PHOTO shows Lieutenant Leigh Wade's disabled plane, the "Boston" being brought alongside the cruiser Richmond after being towed by the larger ship by the destroyer Billingsley. Our photo shows one of the plane's crew on the pontoon prepared to keep the plane from smashing into the ship. Shortly after, the Richmond tried to lift the plane on board. It was then that the tackle broke, the Boston falling back into the water and being smashed so badly that it had to be destroyed. B 9-1-24

WORLD FLIERS POSE AT NATIONAL MUSEUM FOR NOTED SCULPTOR; The World Fliers, the group of six army aviators whose epoch-making flight thrilled the world, have been posing for sculptor Anthony Atchinson who is making a memorial for the round-world flight. The six aviators were all at Mr. Atchinson's studio on Tuesday, December 9, when this photo was taken and the photo shows left to right, Mr. Atchinson, Lieuts. Smith, Harding, Nelson, Ogden, Wade and Arnold. FM & NY&E 12-10-24

SCENE OF THE MISSING COMMANDER OF AMERICA'S ROUND THE WORLD FLYERS, HARBOR OF AKUTAN. ; The Harbor of Akutan, in the Aleutian Islands, 350 miles West of Chignik, is the scene where Major Martin, leader of U. S. round the world flyers, is reported missing, with his flagship, "Seattle" . The Akutan volcano is shown in the background. The harbor, close to the Dutch Harbor, boasts a whaling station and nine families of natives. ; Photo shows whaling station in the harbor of Akutan, scene of the missing Major Martin and his round of the world plane

Moseley, Wright, Thomas and Kennedy were flying in escort planes.
